text.p: Following are the top stories from selected Singapore newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- The Asia-Pacific's economic upswing is set to continue and the region can look forward to higher growth of 4.1 percent this year and next, a leading think-tank predicted.

- The government has formed a committee to recommend ways on how LaSalle-SIA College of the Arts and the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts can play a central role in developing creative and artistic manpower in Singapore.
- A contractor punched his client, breaking his nose and causing it to bleed, when they argued over a patio floor the contractor's workers had stained while carrying out a $800,000 renovation job.
- Acting Malaysian Prime Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim said he could see the Singapore government was now determined to cooperate and be friendly with Malaysia.
- DBS Land's Singapore $428 million share placement stoked speculation that it has serious plans to raise significantly its recently acquired stake in Parkway Holdings.
- Parkway Holding's controlling shareholders, the Tan family, say they might sell their 20 percent stake "if the price is right", echoing the stance of fellow Parkway owners, the Ang family.
- Sembawang Corporation subsidiary Sembawang Maritime (SML) has teamed up with retailer Metro Holdings to enter the potentially lucrative luxury cruise business.
- For the first time in its history, Hai Sun Hup earned more from its soon-to-be-floated hotel division than from its original marine-related activities.
- Shares in Benefun International, Heshe's sister company, rose as much as 48 percent before closing at a 25 percent premium to their offer price.
- Mainboard-listed City Development Ltd's land bank stands at around five million square feet, 86 percent of which is freehold or 999-year leasehold, its recent annual report shows.

- Amcol Holdings' aborted Mauritian joint venture was pushed through speedily in May last year so that managing directors Ng Chee Kheong and Lloyd Lochra could claim credit for the "lucrative" deal, it was claimed in court.
